Game Theory Final Cheatsheet

Repeated Games

  • Bargaining (Rubinstein's model): Recursion Structure

Def. (Repeated Games) The repeated strategic form game G={I,{Ai}i∈I,{gi}i∈I} for T periods. Denote the repeated game as GT. Payoff of player i at stage t: gi(ait,a−it), where at=(ait,a−it) is the action profile at period t.

Example: Repeated Prisoner's Dilemma

  • Find SPE by backward induction. "Defect" is always a dominant strategy.
  • Tit-for-Tat strategy in Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma: Cooperate in round 1. For every round t>1, play what the opponent played in round t−1.

Thm. If every stage G has a unique pure strategy equilibrium a∗, then in the repeated game GT with T<∞, there's a unique SPE where at=a∗ for all t=0,1,⋯,T.

A trigger strategy threatens other players with a punishment action if they deviate from an (implicitly agreed) action profile. Formally writing, A non-forgiving trigger strategy (for player i) takes the following form:

ait={a¯i, if aτ=a¯ for all τ<t a―i,if aτ≠a¯ for some τ<t

Here a¯ is the implicitly agreed action profile and a―i is the punishment action.

  • Prop. In the infinitely repeated Prisoner's Dilemma with δ≥12, there exists an SPE in which the outcome is that both players cooperate in every period. Consider the following symmetric trigger strategy profile:

si(ht)={C, if both players have played C in every periodD, if one player has ever played D in the past

Folk Theorem

Def. Set of feasible payoffs is defined as: V=Conv{v∈RI| there exists a∈A s.t. g(a)=v.}

Def. Player i’s minmax payoff is the lowest payoff that his opponent can hold him to: v―i=minα−imaxαigi(αi,α−i). And the Minmax strategy profile against i: m−ii=arg⁡minα−i[maxαigi(αi,α−i)]. Let mii denote the corresponding strategy of player i such that gi(mii,mi−i)=gi(mi)=vi.

Prop. Individual rationality (IR): In any Nash equilibrium, player i must receive at least v―i .

Thm. (Nash Folk Theorem) If (v1,...,vI) is feasible and strictly individual rational, then there exists δ―<1 such that for all δ≥δ―, there is a Nash equilibrium of G∞(δ) with payoffs (v1,⋯,vI)/(1−δ).

  • proof. Assume there exists a profile a=(a1,...,aI) such that gi(a)=vi,∀i. Consider the following strategies:

    • Play (a1,⋯,aI) as long as no one deviates.
    • If some player j deviates, play mij thereafter (minmax strategy against j).

Thm. (Friedman) Let aNE be a static equilibrium of the stage game with payoffs eNE . For any feasible payoff v with vi>eiNE,∀i∈I, there exists some δ<1 s.t. ∀δ≥δ―, there exists a SPE of G∞(δ) with payoffs v.

 

Two-player Zero-sum game

Payoff matrix: row player R, column player C=−R.

Denote the simplex of available mixed strategies of row player by ∆m (and ∆n​ for the column player)：

∆m={x∈Rm:xi≥0,∑i=1mxi=1},∆n={y∈Rn:yi≥0,∑j=1nyj=1}.

Given a pair of mixed strategy x∈∆m,y∈∆n, the expected payoff of the two players are xTRy and xTCy.

Thm 1. (Von Neumann’s Minimax Theorem) For any two-player zero-sum game with m×n payoff matrices R, C, there is a number z, called the value of the game, satisfying maxx∈∆mminy∈∆nxTRy=z=miny∈∆nmaxx∈∆mxTRy.

Cor 2. There exists a Nash equilibrium in every two-player zero-sum game. (The minimax point)

Def. (Saddle point) A saddle point of a payoff matrix R is a pair (i∗,j∗) s.t maxiRij∗=Ri∗j∗=minjRi∗j.

  • Saddle point ⇔ pure strategy Nash equilibrium.

Thm 3. (Separating Hyperplane Theorem) Suppose that K⊆Rd is closed and convex. If 0∉K, then there exists z∈Rd and c∈R such that 0<c<zTv for all v∈K.

Proof of Thm1. It's obvious that maxx∈∆mminy∈∆nxTRy≤miny∈∆nmaxx∈∆mxTRy.

So we only need to show the opposite inequality. Suppose that miny∈∆nmaxx∈∆mxTRy>λ.

Define a new game with payoff matrix R^ given by R^ij=Rij−λ. So we have LHS is >0.

Construct set K of all vectors which dominate some gain vector R^y∈Rm: K={R^y+v:y∈Δn,v∈Rm,v≥0}

Set K is convex and closed (check Δn and v). Thus according to the Separating Hyperplane Theorem, there exists z∈R and c>0 such that zTw>c>0 for all w∈K. That is, zT(R^y+v)>c>0 for all y∈Δn and v≥0.

We can see that z≥0.

Prop. If the payoff matrix of a zero-sum game is antisymmetric, i.e., Rij=−Rji, then the game has value 0.

Fictitious Play

In every round, each player plays a best response to the opponent’s historical strategy:

it∈arg⁡maxi[eiTR(1t−1∑τ<teτ)],jt∈arg⁡maxj[(1t−1∑τ<teτ)TCej]

Thm. (J.Robin) If the players of a zero-sum game (R,C) interact via fictitious play, then

limt→∞maxieiTRyt=limt→∞minjxtTRej=v,

where v is the value of the row player in the game. (iterative solution)

Bayesian Games: incomplete information

Def. A Bayesian game consists of

  • A set of players I;
  • A set of actions (pure strategies) for each player i: Si ;
  • A set of types for each player i : θi∈Θi ;
  • A payoff function for each player i : ui(s1,⋯,sI,θ1,⋯,θI) (can be extended to mixed strategy);
  • A (joint) probability distribution p(θ1,⋯,θI) over types (or P(θ1,⋯,θI) when types are not finite). (Common Knowledge)

Bayesian: Given p(θ1,⋯,θI), player i can infer the conditional distribution p(θ−i|θi) by Bayes rule.

Def. (Harsanyi's transformation) Games of imcomplete information can be thought as games of complete but imperfect information. In this game, nature makes his first move secretly, which chooses the r.v. (θ1,θ2,⋯,θn), and only informs player i of θi.

Since the payoff, types and prior distributions are common knowledge, we can compute the expected payoffs of player i of type θi as (when types are finite): Ui(σi′,σ−i,θi)=∑θ−ip(θ−i|θi)ui(σi′,σ−i(θ−i),θi,θ−i).

Def. The strategy profile σ is a Bayesian Nash Equilibrium if for all i∈I and for all θi∈Θi , we have:

σi(θi)∈arg⁡maxσi′∈Σi∑θ−ip(θ−i|θi)ui(σi′,σ−i(θ−i),θi,θ−i)

First Price Auction

Consider a first-price auction, where some risk-neutral players bid for one item.

  • Each player’s valuation of the item is i.i.d. on [0,v¯] with c.d.f F, with continuous density f and full support on [0,v¯]. The distribution F is common knowledge.
  • Each one observes his own valuation and decides his bid. The bidder with higher bid wins (tie breaks equally), and pay his bid. Thus, the winner i gets payoff vi−bi , others get payoff 0.
  • Bidder i’s strategy is βi:[0,v¯]→[0,∞].

In the case of two players, and the valuations ∼U(0,1). The strategy profile (β1(v1),β2(v2))=(12v1,12v2) is a BNE.

In general cases: Consider N bidders, with i.i.d. value vi in [0,v¯]. Suppose that bidders j≠1 follow the symmetric and differentiable equilibrium strategy β, where β:[0,v¯]→[0,∞] is increasing and differentiable.

We'll then characterize β s.t. when all other bidders play β, then it is also a best response for bidder 1:

u(b1,v1)=(v1−b1)⋅∏j>1P[bj=β(vj)≤b1]=maxb1Fn−1(β−1(b1))⋅(v1−b1).

First Order Condition Approach: Use first order derivative to maximize this function:

∂∂b1=(v1−b1)(n−1)Fn−1(β−1(b1))f(β−1(b1))1β(β−1(b1))−Fn−1(β−1(b1))=0.

Plug in b1=β(v1),v1=β−1(b1), we will finally obtain

[β(v)Fn−1(v)]′=v[Fn−1(v)]′⇒β(v)=v−∫0vFn−1(x)dxFn−1(v)=E[maxj>1vj:maxj>1vj<v].

Assumptions on auctions:

  • Utility
  • Risk-neutral
  • Quasi-linear & self-interested: the utility for each buyer is a quasi-linear function of his/her own outcome.
  • Additive valuation: ui(o)=vi(xi)−pi=∑jvij⋅xij=v→i⋅x→i−pi.

Second price Auction: the buyer with highest price wins and pays the second-highest price.

  • Optimal strategy: bid your price
  • Key properties: Efficient (maximizing social welfare), Truthful (b(v)=v is indeed optimal).

Vickrey-Clarke-Groves Auction: n buyers for m items, non-additive valuation: ui(o)=vi(x→i)−pi.

  • VCG (family): x→∗=arg⁡maxx→′∈X∑iv^i(x→i′), where X is the set of feasible allocations.
  • Price and utility: pi=−∑k≠iv^k(x→k∗)+hi(v^−i),ui=vi(xi∗)+∑k≠jv^k(x→k∗)−hi(v^−i)

here hi(v^−i)=maxx′∈X∑k≠iv^k(x→k′). (Clarke pivot rule): Best possible income of other agents.

Prop. Truthful, efficient, Individual rationality, no positive transfer; Attack, revenue non-monotonicity

 

Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium

A Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium is a strategy profile σ∗ together with a belief system µ such that

  • At every information set, strategies are optimal given beliefs and opponents’ strategies (sequential rationality): σi∗(hi)∈arg⁡maxEµi(x|hi)ui(σi,σ−i∗|h,θi,θ−i)
  • Beliefs are always updated according to Bayes rule when applicable.

Requirements:

  1. At each infomation set, the player to move must have a belief on which node in the infomation set has been reached by the play of the game. (Prob. distribution over the nodes in the info set)
  2. Given the beliefs. the players' strategies must be sequential rational. That is, the player must take the optimal move given his belief on the information set and other players' subsequent strategies. (A complete plan covering every contingency)
  3. At infomation sets on the equilibrium path, beliefs are determined by Bayes rule and players' equilibrium strategies.
  4. At infomation sets off the equilibrium path, beliefs are determined by Bayes rule and players' equilibrium strategies where possible.

Signaling game

Def. A signaling game involves two players: A sender (S) and a receiver (R).

  • Nature draws a type ti from a set of feasible types T={t1,⋯,tI} according to a probability distribution p.
  • The sender observes ti and chooses a message mj from the message set M={m1,⋯,mJ}.
  • The receiver observes mj, and chooses an action ak from a set of feasible actions A={a1,⋯,aK}
  • Payoffs are given by uS(ti,mj,ak) and uR(ti,mj,ak).

PBE Requirements:

  • (1) After observing mj, the receiver must have a belief on μ(ti|mj).

  • (2R) The receiver's action maximizes his expected utility according to his belief:

    a∗(mj)=arg⁡maxak∈A∑ti∈Tμ(ti|mj)uR(ti,mj,ak)

  • (2S) The sender's message maximizes his utility given the receiver's strategy a∗(mj):

    m∗(ti)=arg⁡maxmj∈MuS(ti,mj,a∗(mj))

  • (3) For each mj∈M, is there exists ti∈T s.t. m∗(ti)=mj, then the receiver's belief at information set mj should follow the Bayes rule and sender's strategy: μ(ti|mj)=p(ti)∑ti∈Tjp(ti). Here Tj denotes the set of the types that send the message mj at equilibrium.

 

Social Choice: Voting Schemes

Def. (Social Welfare) A function W:Ln→L is called a socail welfare function; a function f:Ln→A is called a social choice function.

Unrestricted domains: The domain of W(≻1,≻2,⋯,≻n) must include all possible combination of individual preference relations on A.

Desired properties:

  • Anonymity (i.e. symmetry)
  • Condorcet winner criterion: If a candidate beats all other candidates in pairwise contests, then he should be the winner of the election.
  • Unanimity: if a≻ib for all voters i, then a≻b in social choice.
  • Independent of irrelevant alternatives (IIA): the social preference between any two alternatives a and b depends only on the voters’ preferences between a and b.
  • Non dictatorial: Voter i is a dictator if for all ≻1,≻2⋯,≻n, we have W(≻1,⋯,≻n)=≻i.
  • Monotone: moving A higher should not move A down in society ranking.

Thm. (Arrow's Impossiblity Theorem) Every social welfare function over a set of more than 2 candidates (|A|≥3) that satisfies unanimity and independence of irrelevant alternatives is a dictatorship.

Lemma. (pairwise neutrality) Given unanimity and IIA of W, let π=(≻1,...≻n) and π′=(≻1′,⋯,≻n′) be two vote profiles such that for every voter i, a≻ib⇔c≻i′d. Then a≻b⇔c≻′d, where ≻=W(π) and ≻′=W(π′).

Examples of voting:

  • Plurality Voting: chooses the candidate who is ranked first by the largest number of voters.

  • Runoff: If no candidate has a majority in the first round, then the two leading candidates compete in a second round (India, Brazil, and France). Vulnerable: fails monotonicity

    • Satisfy Condorcet winner/loser criterion? No, Yes.

  • Borda Count: assign a score (n−i) if the candidate ranks i.

    • Satisfies IIA with preference strength, but does not satsify IIA and Condorcet winner criterion.
    • Suffers from manipulation

  • Approval voting: votes can approve as many candidates as they wish

    • satisfies monotonicity

Matchings

Centralized vs Decentralized, Gale-Shapley and stable matching: proposer optimal

Preferences by Compatibility: In this case, we have a matrix A=(ai,j)n×n s.t. i1≻ji2⇔ai1,j>ai2,j and j1≻ij2⇔ai,j1>ai,j2.

  • There exists a unique stable matching.

An allocation is an n-dimensional vector a whose i-th component, ai, is the ID of the house assigned to agent i.

  • Feasibility: ai≠aj for all i≠j. Let A denote the set of all feasible allocations.

A set S of agent is a block coalition for an allocation a if there exists a z∈A(S) such that:

  • for all i∈S, zi⪰iai.
  • exists j∈S that zj≻jaj .

The set of allocations that is not blocked by any subset of agents is called the core.

Top Trading Cycle Algorithm (TTC):

  • Each agent i points to his most preferred house (possibly i’s own, we use the same node to identify the agent and its own house).
  • Give each agent in a cycle the house he points at and remove the agent from the market.
  • Repeat above steps if unmatched agents remain.

Thm. The core of house allocation problem consists of exactly one matching.

  • proof. The outcome of the TTC mechanism cannot be blocked cannot make any agent matched in the first round better off; cannot make any agent matched in the second round better off without making some of the agents matched in the first round worse off; cannot make any agent matched in round n better off without making some agents matched in earlier rounds worse off.

Thm. No person has an incentive to misreport his preferences.

Congestion game & Potential game

Def. A congestion game is defined on a tuple (N,R,A,c), where

  • N is a set of n agents;
  • R is a set of r resources;
  • A=A1×...×An, where Ai⊆2R∖{∅} is the set of actions for agent i;
  • c=(c1,...,cr), where ck:N→R is a cost function for resource k∈R.
  • Denote #:R×A→N as the function that counts the number of players who took any action that involves resource r under action profile a. Then we can define the utility function as: ui(a)=−∑r∈R,r∈aicr(#(r,a)).

Thm. Every congestion game has a pure-strategy Nash equilibrium.

Def. A game G=(N,A,U) is an (exact) potential game if there exists a function P:A→R such that for all i∈N, all a−i∈A−i and ai,ai′∈Ai, ui(ai,a−i)−ui(ai′,a−i)=P(ai,a−i)−P(ai′,a−i).

  • Ordinal potential game: ui(ai,a−i)−ui(ai′,a−i)>0 iff P(ai,a−i)−P(ai′,a−i)>0.

Thm. Every (finite) potential game has a pure-strategy Nash equilibrium.

Thm. Every congestion game is a potential game.

  • By constructing a potential function P(a)=∑r∈R∑j=1#(r,a)cr(j).

Myopic Best Response: While there exists an agent i that is not best responding to a−i Do:

  • ai′← some best response by i to a−i, a←(ai′,a−i).

Thm. The Myopic Best Response procedure is guaranteed to find a PSNE of a potential game.

  • proof. Potential increase strictly in each step of while loop.
